```
    def btn_click(*args):
        set_key(str(uuid.uuid4()))
        on_new_file(file_items)

            accept=".csv", multiple=True, lazy=True, on_file=on_file, dense=True, outlined=True
        ).key(key)
        btn = solara.Button(label="Add", on_click=btn_click)
```

You could trigger a page re-render by changing some other reactive variable if needed

What I'm working on is a customizable RAG model, so someone can upload a custom set of data, the data uses a few different types of ai models to generate embeddings, and then you can "chat" with your dataset.

I have a UI that people upload data to. I calculate a hash of the file, and create a folder with that hash to save the file into. I do this to prevent name collisions.

After files have been uploaded, I want to allow people to see files they have uploaded. The file browser could work here, except I only want to show the files, not the folders with the file hashes.

What I've done is created a display that lists the files with a delete icon. I generate this list by traversing the storage directory to display the file names. Because this isn't a reactive variable, deleting a piece of data doesn't trigger a page reload so the data in the UI isn't removed until the page is refreshed.
Why would you want that? What problem are you trying to solve?
Is there a way to trigger a page reload in code?
Cool!
Yes!
You’re going to Eindhoven? 🙂

Here is a reduced example. https://gist.github.com/Lundez/7763776419d766681a177ef471fb97d8

1. Select model + file
2. Press Run
3. Run Inference, await thread completion
4. Show new Interface with graphs and selection
5. Select cut_off
6. Press run
6. Create video based on ML predictions + cut_off. await thread completion
7. Show video and download button

Btw, I'm heading to PyData. I'll be happy too see you! 😄
Hey! I came here bc I had a problem that my plots are not rendering on the dashboard. Have you encountered this kind of behavior before? I posted my question on questions-issues page.

import solara
import pandas as pd

# Initial data
initial_data = pd.DataFrame([['golf.mp4']], columns=['Name'])
# Create a reactive variable for the DataFrame
files_df = solara.reactive(initial_data)

def add_row():
    # Create a new DataFrame with the added row
    new_data = files_df.value.append({'Name': 'football.avi'}, ignore_index=True)
    # Update the reactive variable
    files_df.value = new_data

@solara.component
def Page():
    solara.DataFrame(files_df.value, items_per_page=5)
    return solara.Button('Add row', on_click=add_row)

# Display the page
Page()
Thanks, got you
Or use a proxy (like a counter) that you increase to signal that the dataframe has changed

you are mutating the dataframe, solara (or any python library) cannot detect that it has changed. you should instead, create a new dataframe and assign to .value that new dataframe (as long as you don't do this with large dataframes, that should be ne performance issue)
When one is pushing the 'add row' button the record is being added to the pandas dataframe, but solara dataframe is updating only if one changes the amount of rows per page

import solara
import pandas as pd

files_df = solara.reactive(pd.DataFrame(
        [['golf.mp4']], columns=['Name']))  

def add_row():
    files_df.value.loc[len(files_df.value)] = ['football.avi']

@solara.component
def Page():
    solara.DataFrame(files_df.value, items_per_page=5)
    solara.Button('Add row', on_click = add_row)

Page()
hi all! I'm using solara.DataFrame to store a list of uploaded video files, but unfortunately the DataFrame is not updating. Any ideas why it doesn't work?
maybe you can write some minimal code as explaination and then I can 'review' that code

It's somewhat what you're saying. I'll try to get pseudo-code to make it clear later. 
My code is to obfuscated by other UI-parts in the flow as is.

But essentially:
1. Fill a form
2. Press button
3. Await long running process
4. Automatically update UI under form
5. Allow a new "sub-form"
6. Follow step 2-4

Is the app logic.
Currently I solve it by setting "is_pressed" to true, which then kicks of a memoized.use_thread if True. But this logic is really not flawless and has quirks.

In on_click I can't use memoize.use_thread but only use_thread(memoize).. that way the UI doesnt update correctly while running.
Hence my "is_clicked" hack

It's difficult to understand what you want to do exactly. Is the problem that you want to call a long running process in the event handler? and once that long running process is done, change a state, which will then update the UI?
The way to do that now is to do this indirect, via use_thread. The event handler changes a state, which triggers a rerender, which triggers the use_thread, which will start the calculation.
Let me know if this is what you want? If so, this is a very common request (cc <@122447467785617409> ) and something we can make simpler in the future.

Im building a quite complex app based on a presentation I did lately.

This app I'm trying to create a control-flow using OnClick (button) but it's a quite awkward flow. Especially as you dont have rendercontext in the lambda (Id like to do a long running action using set_df(longrunning_action) in the lambda) .

Any suggestions on how to create such a flow with nice code and interaction?
yeah, if you are very python focussed, it's nice to be able to just call the python functions you want to use instead of going through REST api's etc.
Clear cache and refresh should fix it

Hi all.  I have just tried to launch my solara application, it opens in my browser and then i get this message: "A widget with mount-id="solara-main" should go here".  I've not changed my code since the last time I was developing, any ideas what this means?  Or what it is caused by?
thanks for your answers
it seems that most of the ML ecosystem is python based and that's why solar seems more friendly, for now, it's hard for me to compare
Better compared to what? Were you thinking of other frameworks, or a separate frontend/backend solution?
is it good to think it is better for AI/ML applications?

Always a good question, short answer of the most important reasons:
 * Define your UI based on the state/data (declarative, like ReactJS)
 * Auto re-executes what is needed (reactive, like Excel)
 * Reusability / encapsulation (components)
   * you can write new ones using the underlying library (ipyvuetify)
   * you can use html/css/js/vue/react to write your own widgets if needed
Together they make it possible to take on larger projects and don't get stuck.

the results.value will be NoneType till the generator returns something, so till it retunrs a type you know it's still RUNNING vs sleeping between iterations.
Alright, so here is how I made it work ` 50     if result.state == solara.ResultState.RUNNING and not isinstance(result.value, NoneType):   `

Gotcha. I think i can make that work. Looks like a lot of the things i do with the value don't work on generators for obvious reasons, but i think i can just add a quick loop to populate a new list from it first... see if that does the trick.
Yeah, if you yield, it keeps in the running state. So you do something like `if result.state == solara.ResultState.RUNNING: solara.Markdown(result.value)`

it's a bit trickier to make it more robust when errors occurs, but result has a .retry method that you can let the user call. For instance, if result.error: solara.Button("....", on_click=result.retry)

My initial idea would be:
```python
@solara.component
def Page(color: str):
    _my_reactive = solara.use_reactive(color)
    my_reactive = solara.use_memo(lambda: MyReactive(color), dependencies[_my_reactive.color])

    solara.Select(label='choose color', value=my_reactive.value, values=my_reactive.get_values(), on_value=my_reactive.set)
    solara.Text(str(my_reactive.value))

Page('red')
```
Could you test if that works, I think it does work in many cases, but i have to think about it a bit longer!

I'm looking for the `use_reactive` equivalent for a subclassed Reactive. This is rougly what i want to do:


```python
@solara.component
def Page(color: str):
    my_reactive = MyReactive(color)

    solara.Select(label='choose color', value=my_reactive.value, values=my_reactive.get_values(), on_value=my_reactive.set)
    solara.Text(str(my_reactive.value))

Page('red')
```

which does not work as it creates a new reactive every render
I kind of expected this to work:

```python
my_reactive = solara.use_reactive(MyReactive)
```

and now i'm doing this:

```python
    def mkreactive():
        return MyReactive(color)
    my_reactive = solara.use_memo(mkreactive, [])
```

which works but isnt great. I know I could do `Page(MyReactive('red'))` but I prefer the `Page('red')` interface

Hi, silly question. I have a DataFrame that gets rendered in my app with column hover capabilities. However, the DataFrame is rather wide and when I hover over the right-most columns, the rendered hover box is out of bounds so that it cannot be seen. I am fairly new to `Solara` and building apps in general. Do you know of a way to force the right-most columns to render the box inside the bounds? Would it involve using css `style` argument? Here is a reproducible example. Thanks!


`
import plotly.express as px
import random
import solara


# Create a dataframe with 15 columns of random floats
df = pd.DataFrame({f'Column_{i}': [random.random() for _ in range(100)] for i in range(15)})


@solara.component
def DataFrameWithHover():

    column_hover, set_column_hover = solara.use_state(None)

    with solara.Column(style='max-width: 400px;') as column_header_info:
        if column_hover:
            fig = px.histogram(df, x=column_hover, title='Histogram')
            solara.FigurePlotly(fig)
    
    with solara.Column():
        solara.DataFrame(
            df,
            column_header_info=column_header_info,
            on_column_header_hover=set_column_hover
        )

DataFrameWithHover()
`

The one thing I have enjoyed about Solara is the need for relatively little boilerplate code.

I did take a look at Reflex awhile ago, and your summary is basically what I found. It is why I decided to stick with Solara when I was just getting started with it.

Good question. Reflex seems to do a 'compile' step using nextjs I think, while solara does everything in Python. Solara works in the Jupyter notebook, I don't think Reflex does that. What I don't know about Reflex is how they handle state inside a component. In Solara, you can have top level / application state using solara.reactive, and per component state using solara.use_reactive. I don't know how Reflex solves that. If you have something to add, please share it with us!
Would be great if you can open an issue on that!
